factoid: Princess Mary wrote "Do not think, however, that my father is ill-disposed toward you."
Princess Mary's father is an invalid.
Princess Mary's father is an old man.
Princess Mary's father must be forgiven.
Princess Mary's father is good.
Princess Mary's father is magnanimous.
Princess Mary's father will love the person who makes his son happy.
Princess Mary asked Natásha to fix a time when she could see her again.
Natásha read the letter.
Natásha sat down at the writing table to answer the letter.
Natásha wrote "Dear Princess" in French quickly and mechanically.
Natásha paused after writing.
Natásha wondered what more she could write after all that had happened the evening before.
Natásha thought "Yes, yes! All that has happened, and now all is changed."
Natásha thought "Must I break off with him?"
Natásha thought "Must I really?"
Natásha thought "That’s awful."
Natásha went to Sónya to escape from dreadful thoughts.
Natásha began sorting patterns with Sónya.
Natásha went to her room after dinner.
Natásha again took up Princess Mary's letter.
Natásha thought "Can it be that it is all over?"
Natásha thought "Can it be that all this has happened so quickly and has destroyed all that went before?"
Natásha recalled her love for Prince Andrew in all its former strength.
Natásha felt that she loved Kurágin.
Natásha vividly pictured herself as Prince Andrew’s wife.
Natásha recalled scenes of happiness with Prince Andrew from her imagination.
Natásha recalled every detail of yesterday’s interview with Anatole.
Natásha sometimes asked herself "Why could that not be as well?"
Natásha thought "Only so could I be completely happy."
Natásha thought "Now I have to choose."
Natásha thought "I can’t be happy without either of them."
Natásha thought "To tell Prince Andrew what has happened is equally impossible."
Natásha thought "To hide it from him is equally impossible."
Natásha thought "With that one nothing is spoiled."
Natásha thought "Am I really to abandon forever the joy of Prince Andrew’s love, in which I have lived so long?"
A maid whispered "Please, Miss!" to Natásha.
The maid entered the room with a mysterious air.
The maid said "A man told me to give you this—."
The maid handed Natásha a letter.
The maid said "Only, for Christ’s sake...".
Natásha mechanically broke the seal of the letter.
Natásha read a love letter from Anatole.
Natásha understood that the letter was from Anatole.
Natásha understood that Anatole is the man she loves.
Natásha loved Anatole.
Natásha held the love letter with trembling hands.
The love letter was composed by Dólokhov for Anatole.
Natásha found in the letter an echo of all that she imagined she was feeling.
The love letter began "Since yesterday evening my fate has been sealed; to be loved by you or to die."
The love letter said "There is no other way for me."
The love letter said "He knew her parents would not give her to him."
The love letter said "There were secret reasons he could reveal only to her."
The love letter said "If she loved him she need only say the word yes."
The love letter said "No human power could hinder their bliss."
The love letter said "Love would conquer all."
The love letter said "He would steal her away and carry her off to the ends of the earth."
Natásha thought "Yes, yes! I love him!"
Natásha read the letter for the twentieth time.
Natásha found some peculiarly deep meaning in each word of the letter.
That evening Márya Dmítrievna was going to the Akhárovs’.
Márya Dmítrievna proposed to take the girls with her.
Natásha had a headache.
Natásha remained at home.
Sónya returned late in the evening.
Sónya went to Natásha’s room.
Sónya found Natásha still dressed and asleep on the sofa.
Anatole’s letter lay beside Natásha on the table.
Sónya picked up Anatole’s letter.
Sónya read Anatole’s letter.
While reading, Sónya glanced at the sleeping Natásha.
Sónya tried to find an explanation of what she was reading in Natásha’s face.
Sónya did not find an explanation.
Natásha’s face was calm, gentle, and happy.
Sónya clutched her breast to keep herself from choking.
Sónya was pale and trembling with fear and agitation.
Sónya sat down in an armchair.
Sónya burst into tears.
